newsitem.title: GERMANY: HOCKEY-AUSTRALIA THRASH U.S. TO REACH TROPHY FINAL.
newsitem.headline: HOCKEY-AUSTRALIA THRASH U.S. TO REACH TROPHY FINAL.

text.p: Olympic and World Cup champions Australia moved into top gear by trouncing the United States 5-0 on Thursday to become the first country to qualify for the women's Champions Trophy final.
Their opponents in the final on Sunday will be Germany, South Korea or the Netherlands.

Germany are best placed to join them after beating Britain 3-0. Their final group match on Saturday -- Friday is a rest day -- is against the Netherlands while Korea meet Australia in a repeat of the Atlanta Olympic final, in their last game of the round robin series.
Australia have 10 points from four games, Germany eight and Korea and Netherlands six.
Australia have improved with every game here after their 1-1 draw with Germany on the opening day. Their win over the U.S. was their biggest ever in their 28 matches against the Americans.
Alyson Annan, again outstanding, gave them the lead in 90 seconds from their first corner with a rasping low drive.

Australia's captain Jennifer Morris added their next two goals, converting a penalty stroke (22nd minute) and a penalty corner (47th) and is now the tournament's top scorer with four goals in four games.
Katrina Powell (55th) and Nicole Mott (57th) completed the rout of the United States, who did not have a shot in the game.
A fine solo goal by local girl Natascha Keller put Germany on the winning path against Britain in the 24th minute.
The German captain, Katrin Kauschke, turned in a cross by Heike Latzsch for Germany's second goal in the 52nd minute and Latzsch herself took advantage of a defensive error to add the third.

Asked if Germany who are unbeaten, could win the Champions Trophy at home, their coach, Berti Rauth, said: "Motivation yes, power no. I have eight new players and they are becoming more confident but the team is tired."

Lee Eun-young, the South Korean inside forward taken to hospital with a neck injury on the first day of the tournament, took the field for the first time since last Sunday to the side to a 2-0 victory over European champions the Netherlands.
Korea were holding a tenuous 1-0 advantage when Lee, who had been wearing a neck brace until Wednesday, was called off the bench to replace another of her team-mates who was injured.
Lee promptly won the ball, took on the Dutch defence and set up a goal by Choi Kwan-sook .
Korea's second win took them from fifth to second place and above the Dutch in the round robin table.
